answerText: SN2 reactions[10] In this synthesis reaction, an alkoxide ion serves as a strong nucleophile to attack a primary alkyl halide or tosylate for form ethers.
heading: ACF Winter |2009 | University of North Carolina, Truman State A, and University of Toronto | 17 | Science | Chemistry | College
subject: Science
question: Question: Answer the following about back-side attacks,  [10] Attack of a nucleophile on the back side of an electrophilic carbon atom to form a transition state featuring complete inversion of configuration occurs in this type of reaction mechanism, in which rearrangement is impossible.
